After having read the short story "The Body" by Stephen King!.I have to say that I feel this film is a very good adaptation of the story.And in some parts improves on the story. The Plot: After his main friend had been killed.Writer Goride Lochance,looks back on a summer in Castle Rock.When he was in his pre-teens.That summer he and three friends (Chris,Teddy and Vern).Who are also helping to support Gordie after his brother sadly died.One day Vern hears his brother and his friends talk about finding a body.The body is of Roy Bower,Who the police have been looking for as a missing person for along time.So Gordie and his friends go on a adventure, and a coming-of-age for all of them. View on the film:The Screenplay: Written by Raynold Gideon and Bruce A.Evans.They make sure the the film moves at a very fast pace. (I feel the short story took a bit to much time to get really going)While most of the flashbacks from the short were taken out,I feel,it makes the movie a lot more easier to know whats happening in the plot.They also make sure to keep the "strong" dialogue scenes from Kings story,while adding really great ones that blend in well with the story ("If Plutos a dog,then whats Goffy?).The only bit that I am unsure about is why the ending was changed,from all of the friends dying,to just one of them.This still has to be,one of the best adaptation of Kings work (wich are usually a bit,lets say "shacky) but this one stands out great.The cast: All of the cast (who were mostly unknown at the time)all work great together,and make you feel that they are really a group of friends.The main part of the film,that you feel the actors brought a lot in and made stronger,is the relationship with Gordie (Wil Wheaton) and Chris (the late River Phoenix),who both in there "breakdown" scenes show great emotion and make the characters more real.The events that happened to Phoenix in real life,makes the ending a lot sadder,then what it was meant to be.Kiefer"24"Suthland,does a really good job in this at playing a very strong,creepy bad guy.(Which is something he used again for The Lost Boys).Direction:Directer Rob Reiner(who would re-team with King,to do Misery),does a really good job at making the setting feel like a very real small town.He also does a really good job at knowing t focus on the people and the story,and not just fill the screen with lots of gore (something that most people get wrong when making a Stephen King story into a film). Final view on the film:The first and still,one of the best book-to-screen movies.And one for anyone who has any great friends will enjoy seeing,or being a fan of Its A Wonderful Life style movies.

Just a note - I wrote this for a school project. I would never have the patience to write something this long otherwise.Stand By Me ***** out of 5 DVD edition Viewed March 4, 2005 Based on Stephen King's bestseller The Body Directed by Ron Reiner Dead Bodies, Vomit, Bloody Leeches, Swearing, Knives and Cigarettes: Why This is the movie for your family By Rachael C., FILMAttention parents! What do you want most for your children? Do you want them to become young, successful and aspiring people? Is it your only wish that Joey and Larissa go out into the wide, wide world and inspire other young people as you inspire them? If so, the 89 minutes of film, which stars the young, successful and aspiring River Phoenix, Will Wheaton, Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell, is for them.But it's full of dead bodies, barfing, bloody leeches, swearing, knives, and cigarettes!, you say. This is not entirely true. The film, released in 1989 by Columbia Pictures, is not merely about a group of friends who travel along a rail track to find a dead body they have heard about. Themes of heroism, self-confidence and friendship are packed together in hilariously heart warming scenes that flow cleanly form frame to frame. Stand by Me is good for both you and your kids to see because of its realistic plot, the talent of the actors and the youthfulness of the movie.The adventure is seen from the point of view of Gordie Lachance (Will Wheaton) who throughout the trip is tortured by the memory of his older brother, who had just died recently. Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell) and Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) all struggle with problems of their own.This movie is what is known as a "coming of age film" featuring characters around 11 to 15 years of age who discover something new about themselves and who they can become through the progress of the story. You may find yourself relating to one of the characters during this movie because the script is incredibly realistic. This reality that you are forced to watch is what will make you both laugh and cry. The way the characters react to each other and the obstacles they face are ways you will remember yourself or your friends reacting. These could just be the facial expressions or words they use, but it conjures up memories of your own childhood. The impeccable performance of the actors in Stand by Me brings in another aspect of realness. The characters are believable, especially in their speech. Although the kids use what is considered to us "foul language", it is how kids of that setting (1950's, fictional town of Castle Rock, Oregon) spoke. The emotions of the audience are constantly changing as each character struggles with his own problems. The main theme of this movie is youthfulness and the friendships we possess at the time. It relishes in both the beauty and the pain of being a kid, as the four friends sing songs at the tops of their lungs, swim in mud, and hold spitting contests, but also experience death, the sheer terror of getting run over by a train and the loss of things special to them(Gordie's hat that his brother gave him). This movie is one your kids will learn something from. And maybe you will learn something from it too. As Teddy Duchamp says, "This is my age. I'm in the prime of my youth and I'll only be young once." Stand by Me will help you relive your youth.

Stand by Me was a movie that truly blew me out of my socks. I saw it first when I was very young and I thought it was great, but completely forgot about it. Over the years, I thought less and less about it until I came across it again one day. I popped it in to see what I had forgotten about, and I found myself crying more than once. It sent a message that children should be receiving very early on. It's a movie about friendship and loyalty. I think my favorite scene was the 'Milk Money' scene. I found myself crying with Christopher Chambers about his dramatic loss and how everyone thought nothing of the 'low-life Chambers kid.' This movie is essentially about four boys looking towards one goal. To be a hero by finding the missing body of Ray Brower and to be redeemed in their town's eyes. And when they set out on their 2-day trek, they learn things about each other that they never knew before. They learn that in each other's eyes they're all equal, and that's all that matters. They learn that they don't need to be redeemed in each other's eyes, because all of them have enough issues with themselves to be able to worry about the issues they have with their friends. But when the rival gang sets out with the same goal and they meet in that last scene, the whole movie pulls together to its ultimate climax. And this group of boys makes for a fun, dramatic and hilarious movie. Teddy Duchamp and Chris Chambers, both doomed to a life of misery by their deranged or angry fathers. Vern Tessio, the sacredly cat with a brother in their rival gang, and Gordie Lachance, perhaps one of my favorite characters in this movie, and the narrator. Gordie is the sensitive writer who just wants a little love from his parents after his brother died in a jeep accident. He was one of the characters that made me cry most, along with Chris.Chris and Gordie are the best of friends, which is something that I think sends out a good message as well. Having a best friend whose shoulder you can cry on and who will always try to be there with you if you ever, in slightly dramatic terms, have a mental breakdown. This movie is highly recommended. Definitely worth seeing, as it has turned into one of my favorites. Especially that one last line:'I never had friends later on in life like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anybody?'
